questions.question: When was the AI Act adopted?
questions.expected_answer: The AI Act was adopted in June 2023.

questions.question: What are the possible sanctions if it is not respected?
questions.expected_answer: Companies or institutions that do not comply with the obligations imposed by the AI Act may face significant fines, which can amount to up to 6% of their global annual revenue.

questions.question: To whom does the AI Act apply?
questions.expected_answer: The legal framework will apply to both public and private actors inside and outside the EU as long as the AI system is placed on the Union market, or its use has an impact on people located in the EU.

questions.question: What is the role of the AI Office regarding the codes of good practice for providers of general-purpose AI models?
questions.expected_answer: The AI Office must encourage, facilitate, and revise the codes of good practice while taking into account international approaches and collaborating with relevant national authorities, civil society organizations, and experts.

questions.question: What must providers of very large online platforms and search engines do to manage systemic risks related to AI usage?
questions.expected_answer: Providers of very large platforms and search engines must assess the systemic risks related to the design and use of their services, including algorithmic systems, and implement measures to mitigate these risks while respecting fundamental rights.

questions.question: Why must AI system providers disclose that content generated or manipulated by AI has been produced by it?
questions.expected_answer: This obligation helps ensure the effective implementation of the European regulation, particularly to reduce systemic risks such as misinformation, which could affect democratic processes and elections.

questions.question: What transparency obligations does the AI Act impose to mitigate the risks associated with AI usage, particularly regarding interactions with machines and AI-generated content?
questions.expected_answer: Limited risk refers to the risks associated with lack of transparency in AI usage. The AI Act introduces specific transparency obligations to ensure that humans are informed when necessary, fostering trust. For instance, when using AI systems such as chatbots, humans should be made aware that they are interacting with a machine so they can take an informed decision to continue or step back. Providers also have to ensure that AI-generated content is identifiable. Besides, AI-generated text published with the purpose to inform the public on matters of public interest must be labelled as artificially generated. This also applies to audio and video content constituting deep fakes.

questions.question: What types of AI applications fall under minimal-risk and are allowed for free use according to the AI Act?
questions.expected_answer: The AI Act allows the free use of minimal-risk AI. This includes applications such as AI-enabled video games or spam filters. The vast majority of AI systems currently used in the EU fall into this category.
